what: Various Tools Related To Backgammon Analysis
title: Various Tools Related To Backgammon Analysis
text: collection useful functions calculations related backgammon. example, ggboard() creates backgammon positions using ggplot2 package. functions calculate take points different flavors, like tp() tp_gammons(), scale certain match winning probability equivalent--moneygame, emg(), way programs like eXtreme Gammon . See function references full overview.

title: Moves from backgammon matches — bgmoves
text: set backgammon moves/decisions matches played Backgammon Galaxy, analyzed GNU Backgammon. Positions total set moves total 309 matches, mostly 3-pointers, played various opponents. analyses files text format, parsed single data frame, using backgammon::galaxy2df()

title: Moves from backgammon matches — bgmoves
Moves from backgammon matches — bgmoves
text: data frame 35,536 rows 21 columns: file name original file; may serve match id date date match player1, player2 nicknames players game_no game number match length match length (unlimited games limit match length) score1, score2 match score, player 1 player2 crawford TRUE Crawford game, FALSE otherwise pos_id position id GNU Backgammon format match_id match id GNU Backgammon format move_no move number play play made, one "Accepts", "Doubles", "Rejects", "Rolls" turn nickgame player made play roll dice roll, applicable (NA cube decision) proper_ca Proper, .e. optimal, cube action, reported GNU Backgammon mistake_ca TRUE cube action mistake made, FALSE correct cube action, NA checker play decision move_err size checker play error, 0 error, NA case move, cube decision cube_err sice cube action error, 0 error, NA case cube available, checker play decision board ASCII text representation board, displayed GNU Backgammon cube_eq ASCII text cube decision equities, displayed GNU Backgammon move_eq ASCII text checker play decision equities, displayed GNU Backgammon

title: Moves from backgammon matches — bgmoves

what: Display a backgammon diagram from an eXtreme Gammon id — ggboard
title: Display a backgammon diagram from an eXtreme Gammon id — ggboard
text: Display backgammon diagram eXtreme Gammon id

title: Display a backgammon diagram from an eXtreme Gammon id — ggboard
Display a backgammon diagram from an eXtreme Gammon id — ggboard
text: xgid character bearoff character. Side bear . Either "right" (default) "left"

title: Display a backgammon diagram from an eXtreme Gammon id — ggboard
text: ggplot object

title: Display a backgammon diagram from an eXtreme Gammon id — ggboard
code: # Starting position: ggboard("XGID=-b----E-C---eE---c-e----B-:0:0:1:52:0:0:3:0:10")   # Middle game position, match to 11, bottom player owns cube ggboard("XGID=-b--BBC-C---cC---cBbc-b---:1:1:1:00:0:0:0:11:10")   # Same position, bottom player to play 51: ggboard("XGID=-b--BBC-C---cC---cBbc-b---:1:1:1:51:0:0:0:11:10")   # Position with multiple checkers off and one on the bar: ggboard("XGID=aFDaA--------------a-Acbb-:1:-1:1:42:3:0:0:7:10")   # Same position, bear off at the left: ggboard("XGID=aFDaA--------------a-Acbb-:1:-1:1:42:3:0:0:7:10", "left")   # Both sides have several points with excess checkers: ggboard("XGID=e----FI------------fd-----:3:-1:1:52:0:0:3:0:10")   # Opening game, match to 3, Crawford: ggboard("XGID=-b---BD-B---cE--abbe----B-:0:0:1:44:2:0:1:3:10")   # Moneygame with beaver and Jacoby rule (Kauder paradox) ggboard("XGID=-BBBBBC------A--caacbbba-A:0:0:1:00:0:0:3:0:10")   # ggboard() returns a ggplot object; you can add title and more id <- "XGID=-a--BBCBB--A-C----bbdbb-b-:1:1:1:00:2:0:0:5:10"  ggboard(id) + ggplot2::labs(title = "Should White double, should Black take?",               subtitle = "This one is tough",               caption = id)   # All checkers off, just to see how that looks like: ggboard("XGID=--------------------------:1:-1:1:00:3:0:0:7:10")

what: Convert outcome distributions from eXtreme Gammon to probabilities — outcome_probs
title: Convert outcome distributions from eXtreme Gammon to probabilities — outcome_probs
text: eXtreme Gammon GNU Backgammon report estimated outcome probabilities cumulative way: number "wins" probability winning ordinary game, gammon backgammon. Sometimes can convenient discrete probabilities.

title: Convert outcome distributions from eXtreme Gammon to probabilities — outcome_probs
Convert outcome distributions from eXtreme Gammon to probabilities — outcome_probs
text: xg_probs numeric vector length 6, corresponding winning chances reported eXtreme Gammon. Can percentages decimal fractions.

title: Convert outcome distributions from eXtreme Gammon to probabilities — outcome_probs
text: named numeric vector length 6, representing outcome probabilities (always sum 1 100)

title: Convert outcome distributions from eXtreme Gammon to probabilities — outcome_probs
code: # XGID=-a-BaBC-A---eE---c-e----B-:0:0:1:00:0:0:0:0:10 # 4-ply winning chances, reported in a cummulative fashion: cum_probs <- c(61.94, 24.09, 1.04, 38.06, 8.54, 0.42) outcome_probs(cum_probs) #>  win_single  win_gammon      win_bg lose_single lose_gammon     lose_bg  #>       37.85       23.05        1.04       29.52        8.12        0.42

text: Put winning probabilities nice table

title: Put winning probabilities in nice table — probs_table
Put winning probabilities in nice table — probs_table
text: probs numeric vector length 6, representing outcome probabilities (must sum 1 100) margins boolean. margin totals added? Defaults TRUE

title: Put winning probabilities in nice table — probs_table
text: data.frame rownames

title: Put winning probabilities in nice table — probs_table
code: # XGID=-a-BaBC-A---eE---c-e----B-:0:0:1:00:0:0:0:0:10 # 4-ply winning chances, reported in a cumulative fashion: cum_probs <- c(61.94, 24.09, 1.04, 38.06, 8.54, 0.42) probs <- outcome_probs(cum_probs) probs_table(probs) #>               Regular Gammon Backgammon    Sum #> Player wins     37.85  23.05       1.04  61.94 #> Opponent wins   29.52   8.12       0.42  38.06 #> Sum             67.37  31.17       1.46 100.00

title:
Compute take points at a given match score, create a nice table
to compare those with money game take points — tp_table
code: met <- get_met() # XGID=-a-BaBC-A---eE---c-e----B-:0:0:1:00:0:0:0:0:10 # 4-ply winning chances, reported in a cumulative fashion: cum_probs <- c(61.94, 24.09, 1.04, 38.06, 8.54, 0.42) probs <- outcome_probs(cum_probs) tp_table(3, 5, probs, 1, met) #>        Cube assumptions Money game take point 3-away, 5-away take point #> 1 Dead cube, no gammons             0.2500000                 0.2091928 #> 2    Dead cube, gammons             0.2784478                 0.2822967 #> 3 Both cube and gammons             0.2466907                 0.2540319
